head.headtext: Role of the judge and jury as to documents

para.paratext: Fed. R. Evid. 1008 provides that when the admissibility of evidence of the contents of writings, recordings, or photographs depends upon the fulfillment of a condition of fact, the question whether the condition has been fulfilled is ordinarily for the court to determine in accordance with the provisions of Rule 104. However, when an issue is raised (a) whether the asserted writing ever existed, (b) whether another writing, recording, or photograph produced at the trial is the original, or (c) whether other evidence of contents correctly reflects the contents, the issue is for the trier of fact to determine.

O.C.G.A. § 24-10-1008 tracks the federal statute. The judge determines if a party has properly authenticated or identified a document. A jury determines if a document is valid. A document must be shown to be what it purports to be before it is received in evidence at all.[1] Regarding the best evidence rule, the court makes a preliminary inquiry as to admissibility, and then the jury determines whether an original ever existed and what document is the original and considers any secondary evidence.[2]
Martin v. State, 135 Ga. App. 4, 217 S.E.2d 312 (1975).
